Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Smart Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site renewal is to offer a unique training opportunity for undergraduates to conduct research in the multidisciplinary area of smart environments, such as homes that are enhanced by information technology to meet residents' needs in a sophisticated and helpful manner. The American population is aging; therefore research is needed to understand the effects of aging and to find ways of allowing older adults and individuals with disabilities to lead independent lives at home. This REU project facilitates research and training in the complementary disciplines of computer science, electrical engineering, psychology, and health care. Because some of the students will be living in apartments that also serve as test sites, they will be fully immersed in the project. It will also make a contribution to a generation whose workforce is trained in multiple, complementary disciplines. The planned recruitment effort and strong mentoring component will spread knowledge of the benefits of the REU program among the targeted populations, resulting in broadening participation in engineering and related disciplines for many years to come. This REU project will continue a tradition of specifically targeting involvement with women and students from underrepresented groups.

This project will enable high quality interdisciplinary research that links design of technology with health-based applications and creates new opportunities for undergraduates to study health and human behavior using the technology. Students will not only be exposed to research environments and techniques, but they will also learn to work with students and faculty in other fields as well. Knowledge from computer science, electrical engineering, psychology, health care, and from other REU programs, is needed to create a smart environment, because an effective smart environment cannot be adequately designed without researching these topics in fully interactive ways, and because a creative smart environment design in turn opens the door to new avenues of health and science research. This interdisciplinary effort is valuable for undergraduate students to research ideas that will have a significant impact on their community. Results of this program, including descriptions of student projects, lessons learned, and quantitative and qualitative feedback, will be disseminated via the program website (reu.eecs.wsu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this REU Site program was to offer a unique training opportunity for undergraduates to conduct research in the multidisciplinary area of smart environments. A smart environment is one in which we deploy sensors, collect and analyze data, and take action to improve performance. Smart environments range from farms, cities, buildings, homes, even to our own bodies. Our REU program facilitated research and training in the complementary disciplines of computer science, electrical engineering, psychology, and health care. Because we partnered with other REU programs on campus, students regularly interacted with other REU students from around the country, with faculty from ours and other REU programs, and with graduate students from the related ongoing research programs in smart environments.

In terms of intellectual merit, this REU site enabled high-quality, interdisciplinary research that links computer science, electrical engineering, and psychology, and provided new opportunities for undergraduates to study how these disciplines can be applied to making environments smarter.  Students are not only exposed to research environments and techniques, but they also learn to work with students and faculty in other fields. Knowledge from computer science and electrical engineering, and from other WSU REU programs, is needed to create a smart environment, because an effective smart environment cannot be adequately designed without researching these topics in fully interactive ways. More information about each project is available on the program website (reu.eecs.wsu.edu), and includes projects in machine learning, data science, robotics, pervasive computing, high-performance computing, sensor design, wearable sensors, energy efficiency, bioinformation, cognitive neuropsychology, and healthcare. These research projects have so far resulted in eight publications including the REU students as co-authors. This interdisciplinary effort is valuable for undergraduate students to investigate ideas that have a significant impact on their community.

In terms of broader impact this REU site helped to attract and retain students from primarily undergraduate institutions and from underrepresented groups, and provided an research experience designed to encourage them to pursue graduate research. Over the three years of the program, we received 378 applications and were able to fund 31 participants from 23 different institutions in 16 different states. Or our 31 participants there were 20 males, 11 females, 17 Caucasian, 4 Hispanic/Latino, 3 African-American, 3 Asian, 1 Native-American, and 3 from other or mixed groups. And 16 of the 31 participants are attending or plan to attend graduate school. Results of this program, including descriptions of student projects, lessons learned, and quantitative and qualitative feedback, are available via the program website (reu.eecs.wsu.edu). This program has also made a contribution to a generation whose workforce is trained in multiple, complementary disciplines. Our recruitment effort and strong mentoring component helped to spread knowledge of the benefits of the REU program among the targeted populations, resulting in broadening participation in engineering and related disciplines for many years to come.
